case_name: V. S. S. V. Meenakshi Achi v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal referred questions to the High Court under section 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: Shah, J. The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal referred under section 66  1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, the following question for the opinion of the High Court of Judicature at Madras

facts.text: War damage receipts of Pound 13,889 and Pound 85,479 received by assessee for assessment years 1954-55 and 1956-57 respectively

anchor.surface_text: Whether the war damage receipts of Pound 13,889 and Pound 85,479 companystitute income of the assessee for assessment in the years 1954-55 and 1956-57 respectively ?

facts.text: Replantation dividend receipts of Pound 20,272 and Pound 14,408 for assessment years 1954-55 and 1956-57

anchor.surface_text: Whether replantation dividend receipts of Pound 20,272 and Pound 14,408 companystitute income of the assessee for assessment in the years 1954-55 and 1956-57 respectively ?

facts.text: Assessee is a firm carrying on business in real estates at Kualakangsar in the Federated States of Malaya

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a firm carrying on business in real estates at Kualakangsar in the Federated States of Malaya.

facts.text: Some properties belonging to assessee constituting stock-in-trade suffered damage during the second world war

anchor.surface_text: Some of the properties belonging to the assessee and which companystituted its stock-in-trade suffered damage during the second world war.

facts.text: Government of India notified a scheme on August 14, 1947 to give relief to Indian nationals in Malaya for losses during Japanese occupation

anchor.surface_text: On August 14, 1947, the Government of India numberified a scheme to give relief to Indian nationals doing business in the Federated States of Malaya who had sustained loss when the territory was under Japanese occupation.

facts.text: Assessee opted for the scheme and obtained tax benefits of Rs. 65,197 and Rs. 1,29,028 for assessment years 1941-42 and 1942-43

anchor.surface_text: Under the scheme, losses suffered by the assessee in Malaya during the war period were allowed to be set off against the assessment year 1942-43 and 1941-42 and the assessee obtained the benefit of Rs. 65,197 and Rs. 1,29,028 in the two years in reduction of tax liability.

facts.text: Government of Malaya set up war damage commission to compensate for properties damaged due to war conditions

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Malaya set up war damage companymission to companypensate persons whose properties has sustained damage due to war companyditions,

facts.text: Assessee received compensation of Pound 14,169 and Pound 5,479 from Government of Malaya in previous years relevant to 1954-55 and 1956-57

anchor.surface_text: and under the scheme devised by the Government of Malaya the assessee received companypensation amounting to Pound 14,169 and Pound 5,479 in the previous years relevant to the assessment years 1954-55 and 1956-57.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, Tiruchirappalli brought war damage amounts to tax in assessments for 1954-55 and 1956-57

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, Tiruchirappalli, in proceedings for assessment years 1954-55 and 1956-57 brought to tax the amounts received by the assessee as war damages from the Government of Malaya.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the order of the Income-tax Officer

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Income-tax Officer was companyfirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal confirmed the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner with slight modification not material

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal companyfirmed the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, subject to a slight modification, which is number material for the purpose of this appeal.

facts.text: Tribunal referred the questions to High Court at instance of assessee

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, at the instance of the assessee, the Tribunal referred the questions, which have been already set out, to the High Court for thier opinion.

facts.text: Assessee conceded that payments received to compensate for loss to properties were subject to tax on income included therein

anchor.surface_text: Payments received by the assessee to companypensate for the loss to those properties were subject to tax on the income included therein. That is companyceded by companynsel for the assessee.

facts.text: Before Income-tax Officer, assessee urged war damage compensation was capital receipt casual and non-recurring not liable to tax

anchor.surface_text: Before the Income-tax Officer it was urged that the companypensation received from the Government of Malaya was a capital receipt of a casual and number- recurring nature, and on that account number liable to be brought to tax.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected the contention and held receipt was revenue representing recovery of revenue loss

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer rejected the companytention and held that the receipt was revenue in that it represented recovery of a revenue loss.

facts.text: Same contention raised and negatived in appeals to Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: In appeals to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and to the Appellate Tribunal the same companytention was raised and negatived.

facts.text: Only contention before revenue authorities and Tribunal was that receipts not taxable under section 4(3)(vii)

anchor.surface_text: The only companytention raised before the revenue authorities and the Tribunal was therefore that the receipts were number taxable because they fell within section 4 3  vii  of the Income-tax Act

facts.text: Contention that only excess over book value taxable raised for first time before High Court

anchor.surface_text: It was for the first time argued before the High Court that since the assets lost or damage retained a certain value in the books of account, only the difference between the amounts received by the assessee and the book value of the assets should be brought to tax.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that after claiming full loss under Central Board scheme, asset value is nil and full compensation taxable

anchor.surface_text: Even if that companytention was open to the assessee, in our judgment, when the assessee put forward the claim for companypensation under the scheme framed by the Central Board or Revenue that its entire property had been lost through enemy action and it obtained relief under the special scheme on that basis, the value of the assets must after receipt of companypensation be taken to be nil,

facts.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.
section 66  1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

issues.text: Whether the war damage receipts of Pound 13,889 and Pound 85,479 companystitute income of the assessee for assessment in the years 1954-55 and 1956-57 respectively ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the war damage receipts of Pound 13,889 and Pound 85,479 companystitute income of the assessee for assessment in the years 1954-55 and 1956-57 respectively ?

issues.text: Whether replantation dividend receipts of Pound 20,272 and Pound 14,408 companystitute income of the assessee for assessment in the years 1954-55 and 1956-57 respectively ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether replantation dividend receipts of Pound 20,272 and Pound 14,408 companystitute income of the assessee for assessment in the years 1954-55 and 1956-57 respectively ?

issues.text: Whether the companypensation received from the Government of Malaya was a capital receipt of a casual and non-recurring nature, and on that account not liable to be brought to tax under section 4 3 vii of the Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: a capital receipt of a casual and number- recurring nature, and on that account number liable to be brought to tax. The Income-tax Officer rejected the companytention and held that the receipt was revenue in that it represented recovery of a revenue loss...the receipts were number taxable because they fell within section 4 3 vii  of the Income-tax Act

issues.text: Whether from the amount of companypensation received from the Government of Malaya, the book value of the assets should be deducted, and only the balance should be brought to tax

anchor.surface_text: under the scheme framed by the Central Board of Revenue, full companypensation for loss suffered by the assessee was number paid, and therefore from the amount of companypensation received from the Government of Malaya under the War Damage Compensation Scheme, in ascertaining the taxable income the book value of the assets should be deducted, and only the balance should be brought to tax.

issues.text: Whether this contention [that only excess over book value taxable] is open to assessee

anchor.surface_text: In our view this companytention is number open to assessee. Before the Income-tax Officer it was urged that the companypensation received from the Government of Malaya was a capital receipt of a casual and number- recurring nature... It was for the first time argued before the High Court that since the assets lost or damage retained a certain value in the books of account, only the difference between the amounts received by the assessee and the book value of the assets should be brought to tax.

issues.text: Whether, when the assessee obtained relief under the special scheme on the basis that its entire property had been lost, the value of the assets must after receipt of companypensation be taken to be nil

anchor.surface_text: Even if that companytention was open to the assessee, in our judgment, when the assessee put forward the claim for companypensation under the scheme framed by the Central Board or Revenue that its entire property had been lost through enemy action and it obtained relief under the special scheme on that basis, the value of the assets must after receipt of companypensation be taken to be nil, and the assessee by number writing off the value in his books of account on and after accepting the benefits of the special scheme companyld number invest those assets for the purpose of assessment to tax with any book value which was liable to be taken into account.

arguments.claim: The compensation received from the Government of Malaya was a capital receipt of a casual and non-recurring nature, not liable to be brought to tax under section 4(3)(vii) of the Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: Before the Income-tax Officer it was urged that the companypensation received from the Government of Malaya was a capital receipt of a casual and number- recurring nature, and on that account number liable to be brought to tax. The Income-tax Officer rejected the companytention and held that the receipt was revenue in that it represented recovery of a revenue loss. In appeals to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and to the Appellate Tribunal the same companytention was raised and negatived. The only companytention raised before the revenue authorities and the Tribunal was therefore that the receipts were number taxable because they fell within section 4 3  vii  of the Income-tax Act

court_response_anchor.surface_text: vii  of the Income-tax Act it was never pleaded that only the excess over the book value was liable to be taxed. The first question referred to the H

arguments.court_reasoning: Receipt held to be revenue representing recovery of revenue loss to stock-in-trade

arguments.claim: The receipt was revenue in that it represented recovery of a revenue loss

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer rejected the companytention and held that the receipt was revenue in that it represented recovery of a revenue loss.

arguments.court_reasoning: Upheld by Appellate Assistant Commissioner, Tribunal, and Supreme Court

arguments.claim: Under the scheme framed by the Central Board of Revenue, full compensation was not paid, so book value of assets should be deducted from the war damage compensation received from Government of Malaya, and only the balance/excess should be brought to tax

anchor.surface_text: Payments received by the assessee to companypensate for the loss to those properties were subject to tax on the income included therein. That is companyceded by companynsel for the assessee. But companynsel for the assessee submitted that under the scheme framed by the Central Board of Revenue, full companypensation for loss suffered by the assessee was number paid, and therefore from the amount of companypensation received from the Government of Malaya under the War Damage Compensation Scheme, in ascertaining the taxable income the book value of the assets should be deducted, and only the balance should be brought to tax.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: eceived by the assessee and the book value of the assets should be brought to tax. Even if that companytention was open to the assessee, in our judgme

arguments.court_reasoning: Contention not raised before lower authorities; even if open, asset value treated as nil after claiming full loss under CBR scheme

arguments.claim: The contention that only excess over book value is taxable is not open to the assessee as it was not raised before revenue authorities or Tribunal, where only argument was that entire receipt is capital/non-taxable under section 4(3)(vii)

anchor.surface_text: In our view this companytention is number open to assessee. Before the Income-tax Officer it was urged that the companypensation received from the Government of Malaya was a capital receipt of a casual and number- recurring nature... It was for the first time argued before the High Court that since the assets lost or damage retained a certain value in the books of account, only the difference between the amounts received by the assessee and the book value of the assets should be brought to tax.

arguments.claim: When assessee claimed and obtained full relief under CBR scheme on basis of entire property lost, asset value must be taken as nil thereafter, so full compensation from Malaya war damage commission is taxable in entirety as profit

anchor.surface_text: Even if that companytention was open to the assessee, in our judgment, when the assessee put forward the claim for companypensation under the scheme framed by the Central Board or Revenue that its entire property had been lost through enemy action and it obtained relief under the special scheme on that basis, the value of the assets must after receipt of companypensation be taken to be nil, and the assessee by number writing off the value in his books of account on and after accepting the benefits of the special scheme companyld number invest those assets for the purpose of assessment to tax with any book value which was liable to be taken into account.

holdings.text: The answer to the second question will be governed by judgment in Civil Appeals Nos. 157-158 of 1965, V. S. S. V. Meenakshi Achi v. Commissioner of Income-tax, and need not be considered in these appeals

anchor.surface_text: The answer to the second question will be governed by judgment in Civil Appeals Nos. 157-158 of 1965, V. S. S. V. Meenakshi Achi v. Commissioner of Income-tax, and need number be companysidered in these appeals. The only question which has to be decided is the first question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue deferred to concurrent decision in related appeals

holdings.text: In our view this contention is not open to assessee

anchor.surface_text: In our view this contention is number open to assessee. Before the Income-tax Officer it was urged that the companypensation received from the Government of Malaya was a capital receipt of a casual and number- recurring nature, and on that account number liable to be brought to tax. The Income-tax Officer rejected the companytention and held that the receipt was revenue in that it represented recovery of a revenue loss.

holdings.reasoning_summary: New argument on partial taxability (excess over book value) not raised before revenue authorities or Tribunal, where only full exemption under section 4(3)(vii) was claimed

holdings.text: when the assessee put forward the claim for compensation under the scheme framed by the Central Board of Revenue that its entire property had been lost through enemy action and it obtained relief under the special scheme on that basis, the value of the assets must after receipt of compensation be taken to be nil, and the assessee by not writing off the value in his books of account on and after accepting the benefits of the special scheme could not invest those assets for the purpose of assessment to tax with any book value which was liable to be taken into account

anchor.surface_text: Even if that companytention was open to the assessee, in our judgment, when the assessee put forward the claim for companypensation under the scheme framed by the Central Board or Revenue that its entire property had been lost through enemy action and it obtained relief under the special scheme on that basis, the value of the assets must after receipt of companypensation be taken to be nil,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Full loss relief claimed and obtained under CBR scheme treats assets as totally destroyed, reducing book value to nil for subsequent compensation calculations

holdings.text: Compensation received in replacement of those assets by the assessee from the war damage commission must therefore be treated in its entirety as profit liable to tax

anchor.surface_text: Compensation received in replacement of those assets by the assessee from the war damage companymission must therefore be treated in its entirely as profit liable to tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Receipts substitute revenue loss to stock-in-trade; not capital/casual/non-recurring under section 4(3)(vii); full amount taxable post-nil valuation

holdings.text: The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with costs

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirming lower courts' determination that war damage receipts are taxable income

anchor.surface_text: In our view this contention is number open to assessee. Before the Income-tax Officer it was urged that the companypensation received from the Government of Malaya was a capital receipt of a casual and number- recurring nature, and on that account number liable to be brought to tax. The Income-tax Officer rejected the companytention and held that the receipt was revenue in that it represented recovery of a revenue loss.
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.
